entry.et: Middle English leest, from Old English lǣst, superl. of lǣssa less

def.dt: :lowest in importance or position
:smallest in size or degree
:being a member of a kind distinguished by diminutive size the least bittern
:smallest possible :slightest
:one that is least
:at the minimum at least once a week
:in any case at least you have a choice
:in the smallest or lowest degree
:especially not no one, least of all the children, paid attention

entry.et: Middle English, partly from Old English lǣs, adverb & noun; partly from lǣssa, adjective; akin to OldFrisian lēs less

def.dt: :constituting a more limited number or amount less than three less than half done
:of lower rank, degree, or importance no less a person than the president himself
:of reduced size, extent, or degree
:more limited in quantity in less time
—used to emphasize that something is regarded as impressive or surprising wants to be driven to the airport, in a limousine no less

entry.pt: The traditional view is that less applies to matters of degree, value, or amount and modifies collective nouns, mass nouns, or nouns denoting an abstract whole while fewer applies to matters of number and modifies plural nouns. Less has been used to modify plural nouns since the days of King Alfred and the usage, though roundly decried, appears to be increasing. Less is more likely than fewer to modify plural nouns when distances, sums of money, and a few fixed phrases are involved less than 100 miles an investment of less than $2000 in 25 words or less and as likely as fewer to modify periods of time in less (or fewer) than four hours.

entry.et: Middle English littel, from Old English lȳtel; akin to Old High German luzzil little

def.dt: :not big: as
:small in size or extent :tiny has little feet
:young was too little to remember
:small in comparison with related forms used in vernacular names
:having few members or inhabitants a little group little towns
:small in condition, distinction, or scope big business trampling on the little fellow
:narrow mean the pettiness of little minds
:pleasingly small a cute little thing

dt.un: used as an intensive why, you little devil!

def.dt: :not much: as
:existing only in a small amount or to a slight degree has little money
:short in duration :brief
:existing to an appreciable though not extensive degree or amount used with a had a little money in the bank
:small in importance or interest :trivial
:in only a small quantity or degree :slightly facts that were little known at the time
:not at all cared little for their neighbors
:rarely infrequently
:the least common multiple of two or more denominators
:the smallest common multiple of two or more numbers
:the common multiple of lowest degree of two or more polynomials
:a method of fitting a curve to a set of points representing statistical data in such a way that the sum of the squares of the distances of the points from the curve is a minimum
:a very small black-capped tern (Sterna antillarum) with a white body and forehead that is found chiefly in coastal areas of eastern North America and California
